abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Transport Development
            Project for Mongolia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            significant, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: use
            of trials and pilots in the case of countries facing severe
            climatic conditions is important. During the project several
            pilots of alternative road surface designs were carried out.
            Pilots are helpful to assist with the selection of proper
            technologies given the conditions of Mongolia: harsh
            weather, long distances making it costly to carry road
            construction materials, sparse population making it
            difficult to secure personnel to carry out road maintenance.
            Since Mongolia road engineering standards were relatively
            old and inadequate, such trials and pilots were essential to
            assess proposed new standards before they were adopted.
            Better-than-average project preparation is necessary in
            countries with short construction seasons. Countries with
            long and harsh winter conditions such as Mongolia only have
            a few months when conditions allow for carrying out road
            improvement works. Thus, better and more rigorous planning
            and procurement compared to other countries is necessary to
            ensure that works can be scheduled and implemented in a way
            that maximizes utilization of the short construction season,
            thus minimizing the cost of road works and facilitating an
            early completion of the works.

437705.trustfund:
TF040117-MONGOLIA: PREPARATION OF
            ENVIRONMENTAL CODE OF PRACTICE,TF039416-MONGOLIA - TRANSPORT
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF036118-MONGOLIA - TRANSPORT
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Transport Development Project, will
            improve accessibility to the isolated, and remote central,
            and western regions of Mongolia, and, increase transport
            capacity for rail-borne export trade. The components
            include: 1) reconstruction of the paved road from Erdenesant
            to Arvaikheer, based on technical, and economic assessments
            for alternative types of rehabilitation, of some twenty six
            sections of the road, of which, those with the highest
            weighed economic rate of returns, were selected for
            improvement. In addition, short sections of the road from
            Arvaikheer to Khovd, will be upgraded, to provide an
            all-weather gravel surface, with additional short sections
            of the road from Kharkorin to Tosontsengel, improved as
            well, with an all-weather gravel surface; 2) technical
            assistance (TA), and training provision, to support the
            advisory Road Board, including co-sponsoring visits to other
            transition countries, with similar, and established road
            boards. The component will complement a grant from Sweden,
            which provides training in contract management to the
            Department of Roads personnel; 3) road safety, and
            implementation of a system of registration, and inspection
            of road vehicles, complementing inspection facilities,
            funded by previous operations, with additional testing lines
            for trucks, and light vehicles; 4) supply of maintenance
            equipment to ensure road maintenance; and, 5) TA to
            establish the railway financial accounting system, to
            complement the existing management information system, thus,
            facilitate the use of financial, and physical resources.

1003136.trustfund:
TF040117-MONGOLIA: PREPARATION OF
            ENVIRONMENTAL CODE OF PRACTICE,TF039416-MONGOLIA - TRANSPORT

repnme.cdata!:
Mongolia - Transport Development Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment identifies
            potential negative impacts resulting from the
            rehabilitation, and upgrade of three road links to be
            implemented under the Transport Development Project, and,
            recommends appropriate mitigation measures to minimize
            environmental impacts. It provides a brief description of
            the legislative framework, and discusses the screening
            methodology used for its analysis. River basins are
            permanently affected by the influence of freezing, and
            thawing processes, affecting not only roadways, but soil
            erosion in general, as sedimentation trends are current, due
            to wind conditions, and intensify arid zones, while
            groundwater resources are scarce, mostly due to stony, and
            dry streambeds with high water absorption, endangering the
            region's flora and fauna, as well as alpine tundra
            forests. Mitigation measures stipulate that: 1) excavation,
            embankment, and grading works will ensure sedimentation
            control of water courses in, or adjacent to work areas,
            securing clean surfaces of undisturbed soil and rock, and,
            low areas will be filled with on-site material from the
            cutting operations, facilitating drainage of surface runoff.
            A buffer zone of undisturbed vegetation will be maintained
            between water courses, and works, protecting its outflow
            location; 2) wastes, and oil spills will be appropriately
            stored at selected land sites for final disposal; 3)
            critical habitats will be flagged, and avoided as possible,
            followed by re-vegetation to control surface erosion,
            incorporating certified, rapid seed mixes to improve the
            degraded topsoil.
